title: A Comprehensive Watch Guide
text:
Sinn 556
If you‚Äôre anything like me, you scour the internet for all types of information related to watches. From the cheapest automatic chronographs to the most commonly used movement. Here we will explore these topics and many more, from comparing dive watch case diameter trends over the years, to price trends from popular brands like the Rolex Datejust.

title: A Comprehensive Watch Guide
text:
üîç Explore the Watch Dataset
We will be using a dataset I built using AI, as well as manual searching. This is a work-in-progress list and will be updated as we go. For right now, some values such as prices are a bit off, I will try to ensure accuracy as this project grows.






In this dataset, we have some pretty standard information, such as dimensions of the watch, movements, etc. What I really want to pinpoint in the future is comparison between types of movements and prices. As we‚Äôre all watch fanatics, most of us want to find the best deal we can on the watch with maybe not the most name recognition, but the most bells and whistles. This is what this dataset will be primarily be focused on.
As you can see above, the list is not nearly exhaustive as I want it to be, we will be starting out with 600 models and moving on from here. If you have a specific model or brand you want to look up, you can use the search bar above to pinpoint all datasets I currently have of them.

title: Chronographs vs.¬†Divers
text:
Tag Heuer Monaco vs Oris Divers SixtyFive
Chronographs and Divers are staples in any watch collection. What we‚Äôll be exploring here is price differences and popularity between the two.

title: Chronographs vs.¬†Divers
text:
‚åö Chronograph vs Diver: Price Comparison









Looking at our first chart, chronographs seem to have a larger range of prices, for the low and high end markets, but chronographs have a higher average price, this means, on average, a chronograph will cost you more than a dive watch.

title: Chronographs vs.¬†Divers
section: ‚öôÔ∏è Movement Type Distribution in Chronograph vs Diver
text:
‚öôÔ∏è Movement Type Distribution in Chronograph vs Diver









Looking at our second chart things get more interesting. While there are more options for divers in terms of price range, it seems like more divers are made overall, and of those are automatic movements. Manual winded divers seem the least popular, and much less popular than their manual winded chronograph rival, which makes sense, Omega Speedmaster Professional is probably propping up that stat by itself.

title: Average Prices
text:
üìä Average Price by Brand
A tertiary glance at watch prices on any of the big brands these days send a chill down my spine, and should you. It seems watch brand prices just keep going up, while movements and case materials remain stagnant, and when materials do change, these brands charge an arm and a leg (looking at you Rolex.)



Rolex Titanium Yacht-Master 42


But it isn‚Äôt all doom and gloom, a lot of micro brands and entry level friendly brands still offering great bang for your buck. So without further ado, lets look at our entire dataset and look at some common trends on prices these days.









Prices just seem to be going up, and watches are no exception. All of the big brands are about where you‚Äôd expect, with the ‚ÄúHigh Horology‚Äù trio dominating. Blancpain and Zenith are also unexpectedly high, followed by main staples such as Rolex and other top luxury brands.









Looking at used prices is another story, however. Values for Patek Philippe on the used market actually do BETTER than their new counterparts. Just goes to show how well their new marketing strategy has been working out for them by artificially creating demand they just keep generating more buzz. AP also seems to retain their value, but the rest do show depreciation.
